She also takes 20 freaking pills a day, for what I dont know.  And we all know her cancer is soooooo much worse than mine.  BITE ME!  My sisters and I barely talk anymore because I just couldnt deal with their "just be positive and the universe will take care of it" BS!  I just chalk it up to people are just stupid, period end of discussion.  Stillvertical~If you click on a topic that has "rant" in the subject line (or any topic, especially stage 3ers), please be respectful.  This is OUR SAFE PLACE.  Please feel free to see yourself out without causing more chaos to our lives. Anger is a part of this disease, if you havent gotten there yet fine but please dont judge those of us who appropriately handle our emotions.   Sheila~ I dont think anyone has a problem with you chiming in here.  Rant away girl!  Thats what we are here for.  Smooches   Congrats on your almost 5 years!  Woo Hoo!  As far as your family or friends go, that stinks.  I am sorry that they dont support you and offer you an ear when you need it, they really just dont understand, but we DO.  So rant away to us anytime, WE GET IT. Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2009 09:30AM cherneski wrote: What a good friend you are!  My best friend bailed on me when I was DX.  Just be there for her.  Listen to her.  Make food for her,  even if she is not eating make something up (I like soft mushy foods like mac n cheese, zity).  Bring it to her.  Even it her hubby eats it instead of her.  Go grocery shopping for her, clean her house.  If you dont think her hubby would flip maybe find some literature about support groups for him and let him know you left some papers for him to look at in his own time.  Our DHs suffer so much with us and they DONT know how to let it show.  I am sure he is so scared and reacting out in anger and stuffing everything with booze.  I hate to seem like you should cater to him but I think it will make life easier for her.  Let him know that you are there to help both of them.  I am sure you have enough to do yourself.  So, co-ordinate with her friends and family who is going to help and when.  Who will come over to cook, and clean, who will run what errands and when.  Contact some support groups yourself to see what help you can get for her.  She is probably unable to do it herself. Of course she is no fun anymore!  She NEEDS HELP AND UNDERSTANDING!  Thank God for you.  Bless you. Hugs and prayers. Just keep being a good friend.

Posts.Content: cherneski wrote: Hello Lovelies, I am scheduled for a unilateral mastectomy May 6th.  If my BRCA comes back positive (and if it comes back before then) I will opt for a bilateral. I see so many women that opt for I bilateral.  Would my Dr. do this if I chose this event without BRCA +.  Does insurance pay for a bi if it is your choice? I am not eligible for immediate recon as I smoke.  Yes I plan on quitting however now all I do is chain smoke since my DX.  If they don't do immediate recon how will they get my skin that big again?  I am DD and if they take all the skin away wont it take forever for it to grow back again.  Is that why some of you have tissue expanders?  When will they put the expander in? What is an exchange?  I see some posts about being in the hospital for a day or so.  I am scheduled for outpatient same day is this normal? After just surgery not including chemo or rads how long are you kept out of work?  I am required to lift 40 lbs over my head at my job and work in a very dirty germy place?  If I get rads can I still reconstruct?  I have heard that not everyone loses their hair, but from what I have seen breast cancer patients lose their hair.  Is there any possibility I will not lose my hair.  How long does it take before your hair falls out?  And how long before it starts to grow again?  I am definitely getting chemo we just don't know what kind and for how long. How long will I be under the weather after the surgery?  How bad is the pain? How long will I be in pain. Thank you all so much this board is such a blessing. Hugs Deb Deborah dx 38 DCIS, IDC, ILC, BRCA- 6 rounds Taxotere+Cytoxin, 25 rads. Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2009 08:14PM cherneski wrote: Hi again all.  I don't post much, mostly because I feel like a buzz kill.  I have had pretty bad SE on TC, I get sever bone pain that causes me not to be able to walk.  Onc. put me on round the clock oxycotin, with a side kick of percotets.  I am terrified to become addicted, but I have to take them so I am not in tears everytime I walk.  Onc. told me by the time of my 5th or 6th TX I may need to go on a pain patch, I think fentanyl, that scares me even more. My moods are insane.  My 1st TX wasn't THAT bad but each TX after has gotten twice as bad as the one before.  My taste buds are all screwed up.  Most things taste like crap to me.  When chocolate doesn't taste good you know you are screwed up.  A week and a half after TX #3 I started a new nightly ritual of puking at 2 am, but last night and tonight it has moved to 9pm.   Also what started with 2-3 days of being bad I now have almost 2 full weeks of feeling like total crap.  I too have 3 more TXs to go.  I am not looking forward to them.  I am scared to death of my next one as if they just keep getting worse how bad can the next one be.  October 6th will be my last chemo.  I cant wait!  But it seems sooooooo far away.  I keep trying to look at I am a little more than half way there.  Congratulations to everyone done.  I wish you all the best in your next part of your journey.  Thank you all for being so positive. Imt041409, I just spoke to my onc. today about sex.  My problem is not that I don't have the drive, cause I do, but that I just cant get there anymore.  There is a thread "give me back my mojo" on here (at least I think that is what it is called).  She told me it is so unfortunate that the issue is not addressed, in the medical field.  It has been addressed for men; why not women?  See what I mean about me being a buzz kill.  I asked her if I could try some of the pills you see on TV or in the stores that promise you the world.  She told me I can as long as they don't have estregen.  She asked me to kinda do some research and whatever I find that works to please let her know so that she can recommend it to other patients.  She is as upset about this as I am.  I think she is more upset than me that the issue just gets no respect.  She also suggested I start a support group in the cancer center with woman going through the same issues.  I was amazed at her confidence in me.  Does anyone know of a cream or pill that will help with making it to mojo land?  I miss being there.  hugs to everyone
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2009 12:28AM cherneski wrote: I had my pet scan after surgery, no other cancer found, but 3 areas they want to check after chemo is done.  I too get Decadron in my iv with chemo, and now pills of it too.  My first 3 tx I had a great appetite with the steroids, but halfway through tx #3 I started getting sick every day.  That is why onc. gave me pills and increased my dose.  Onc. also gave me Ambien to help me sleep as I dont sleep normal at all.  I will stay up for 2-3 days then sleep for 12-18 hours.  I would not recommend Ambien for anyone.  I stopped taking it after day 3 because of terrible side effects.  Read up on it before you take it if you do.  Know what can happen. My vision is all screwy, onc. said it will get better after chemo is done. I am tired of it all too.  But trust me they dont tell me how positive I am, I am a lunatic.  I crash very hard from the steroids and the pain makes me miserable most of the time.  I just want it all to be done with.  I still have a few brows hanging on so at least when I want to pencil them in I have a dotted line.  Funny thing about my lashes is I swear they are getting thicker.  Maybe that is just my bad vision. Hugs to you all. 4 down 2 to go!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 12:45PM cherneski wrote: Carolyn, I had a bi-ms in May.  Right breast had cancer, I was offered lump, but was told that once they went in they may be forced to do mas.  They would have had to do mas. as I had IDC, DCIS, ILC in different quadrants (spelling).  I have not had recon yet, I probably will later.  I am disfigured but I DO NOT regret it.  My healthy breast was removed and onc. and bs told me it was a good choice as I probably would have been back with cancer in a short time.  I had about 75 staples across my chest.  I have zipper scars.  They left as much tissue as possible, so I have little mounds but mostly under my arm, not where the breast would be.  They leave as much as possible for recon.  I do have some feeling on my mounds again, the feeling is just starting to come back.  I was told I will have numbness forever in some areas.  The sx was not bad.  Pain was tolerable with pain meds.  I cried terribly at first look.  I miss my breasts.  I miss life before cancer.  BUT I DO NOT REGRET IT!  I feel I did waht I think is/was the best possible thing for my health and my mental well being.  Sometimes I think I am oddly comfortable with how quick I got used to not having them.  Most days I am good with it, some days I still cry.  Best of luck, hope this helps.  Feel free to PM me with questions.  I will answer anything I can. Hugs

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 01:01PM cherneski wrote: Things that I didnt expect and were not told to me... I If you dont do immediate recon, they save as much skin and tissue as possible, so it is kinda placed under my arm, towards the outside of my chest, they call them dog flaps.  They are a little uncomfortable and dont look very nice, but livable.                                                             I had over 70 staples across my chest, although my scars are not nearly as bad as they sound.  I thought I would be totally flat, like a board, but I still have very tiny strange shaped boobies.       I have no nipples but I did know that going in.                                                                           I had lots of numbness, and still some to this day.  I was told I would always have some, and some of it is in my back.  If they remove lymph nodes be very very careful lifting and injury to the hands and arms as to not get lymphedema.  I had 13 nodes removed 7 positive, I knew the risk of lymphedema, but got a very very small paper cut on my ring finger, I didnt think much of it as I was always washing my hands.  Low and behold 3 days later 3 fingers and part of my hand I have mild lymphedema.  The hardest part about having my breast removed is just like you think, not having breast.  I loved my boobies, sure I complained that they sagged and they were heavy, but they were mine.  And make no mistake I wanted to keep them.  So yes it is hard on some days that they are gone, I miss them, but also to be totally honest, I kinda like the fact that when it is hot I can just take off my bra and walla I am cooler~lol, or if they get too heavy.  So I try to focus on that.  I think I got used to not having them really early.  The first look in the Drs office was terrible.  Then I couldnt even look for quit a while.  I did not associate them with cancer, I associated them with me, with breastfeeding 4 children, with the fact that they helped me get a few boyfriends in my day, with the fact that they were my husbands favorite part of my body.  So yes that part is the hardest.  Physically it is a cake walk compared to chemo.   You will get through this.  Just another bump in the road.  Feel free to ask any questions here or via PM as sometimes this board is a bit too much for me to keep up on with chemo brain and all.  Hugs

I bathed my cats in Dawn dish soap, a home remedy I found on line.  Wow all those little buggers are dead.  My cats didnt like it much at all.  Poor little guys.  But I gotta say it was funny as heck.  After I bathed the kitten he flew out of the bathtub and was jumping at the doorknob trying to open it.  Mamma cat has run and is still hiding.  OMG what a mess.  Tomorrow I get to get Borax detergent for the furniture and floors as that is another non toxic remedy I found and people swear by it.  Tonight I will put bowls of water in the middle of the floors with a drop of Dawn in them as apparently the fleas will jump in and drown.  The thing that freaked me out so bad is that my 6 y/o daughter is so bit up.  Yesterday she was fine, today she is not and I found 2 in her hair!  So I found a home remedy for that too.  Hopefully it wont be as bad as I think. After not sleeping all night and not having anything stay in my belly for 2 day, I was just done.  I sure hope I can sleep tonight and keep down this pasta. Candy, you are so beautiful I would have thought your are younger than me.  After all this is done I think I will treat myself to botox for my crows feet also.  I hope I get motivated to loose some weight and get rid of my double, triple chin too. glanders no way are you an imposture!  You are going through this just as real as all of us.  I am just unfortunate and get bad SE.  The emotions are still the same, I just get pain a lot of pain with mine.  After a few hours of sleep I feel better and can think ok only 3 more to go.  I can do this! hugs Debi

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2009 08:33PM cherneski wrote: HI ALL!  Today was a wonderful day!  It couldn't have been better if I planned it myself.  I went to Look good feel better make up class today.  They also have one for wigs that I went to months ago but the girl that runs it wasn't there and the choices were so yucky.  But I was given 2 wigs at that time, they were not my color or style, I thought I would have them cut and dyed but never did for fear of ruining them, so they just sit.  I wear scarves and hats, and I am / was perfectly happy with that.  Well after my make up was all done they had me model a wig.  I burst into tears and couldn't stop crying.  The girl running the class felt so bad cause she is not allowed to give out the wigs in this class.  I didn't realize how much I miss my hair until I had a wig that looks good on me.  I tried to compose myself and couldn't.  I went to the bathroom to take a pic to send to my DH and still couldn't stop crying.  I looked so good.  Not my usual cut or color, lighter color and a much softer cut (makes me look less angry at the cancer).  I know most of the girls that work at the cancer center, and by the time I was walking back from the bathroom (still crying) they had arranged for me to keep the wig!   WOW I really miss having hair!  I didn't even know it!  I came home and surprised DH, he loves it!  I walked (yes walked) to pick up DD from school and she didn't recognize me!  All the parents know it didn't grow overnight and I got so many compliments!  I was floating!  I think I still kinda am! I am a week out of tx #5, they dropped my Taxotere in half and wow what an improvement!  I can eat!  I don't feel like I am gonna puke every second.  I don't puke up all my food.  I have a bit of energy!  I still have lots of pain, but when you have energy and don't feel so out of control the pain is much more bearable.  I stopped wetting my pants (thank you God).  My feet are still a little screwy, but hey I cant ask for everything! There is a light at the end of the tunnel and I can see it!  2 weeks till my last (hopefully) chemo!  I thought I would NEVER feel this good again.  I really thought I wasn't going to make it!  I was so ready to just quit! I still cant sleep right, cant think right, but life is GOOD today! DH drew me a bath with candles, I laid in there for about an hour until I was falling fast asleep (figure get out before I drown~lol).  My kids were well behaved.  My oldest DS (who loves to give me a run for my money) was helpful all day.  My 14 DD didn't act like she was 14 today, she said Grace at dinner, then after dinner cleaned everything without being asked to and didn't want anything for it.  My little ones kept telling me how pretty I am that they love my new wig! I am the complainer here and I know it.  So sorry but most days I can barely stand being in my body.  So I thought I would share how terrific today was!  Thank you all so much for always being there for me.  I really don't know what I would do without all of you.  So much love!  Heres to hoping everyone has a day like I had today tomorrow and always. Smooches!  Oh yeah I asked the nurse what medication they give me to cause amnesia and she looked at me like I had 3 heads, and told me they don't. She thought it was just chemo brain.  I will ask the nurse practitioner that told me about them last week what it is when I see her next.  ONWARD!

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2009 08:35AM cherneski wrote: Michelle, I had bilat no recon, I was wired something fierce the day of surgery, I paced my hospital room till about 6am the next day (anesthesia works really weird on me after I wake up).  But then crashed.  I was allowed to stay overnight in the hospital.  Not sure if I could have stayed longer.  I was probably totally out of it for about 2 days after that.  But I was not back to normal for about 4 weeks or so.  I was unable to shower as I had a surgical bra on and was packed with dressings, and drains hanging out.  I had 3 drains, 2 were taken out 5 days post surgery, and the other one 8 days post surgery.  I was able to shower after drains were out.  I pretty much took a shower from the waist down and washed my hair with help until then.  I had my staples removed in just under 2 weeks.  Please be very careful about lifting and injury if they remove lymph nodes.  My BS told me not to worry about lymphedema, well low and behold, I had a small (very small) paper cut on my finger one day then 3 days later lymphedema.  Do your exercises but be careful please.  For some reason I still have almost all of my eyebrows and I swear my eyelashes are thinker than before.  I dont get it.  The fuzz that grows on my legs get annoying.  I would trade my eyelashes and brows for pain any day. I know there are some of us still getting TC and other txs.  But are any of you just so tired of it that you are ready to quit?  I have 2 more txs and I kinda feel like a zombie walking to my next one tomorrow.  I feel so defeated.  More side effects, I just cant take much more.  I know it will be worse this time.  Not trying to sound negative, but history has been proven, each one gets worse and I get new SEs.  Pretty sure I got neorpathy last time, and I am terrrifed it is gonna come back and stay.  I am losing feeling in my right hand. I read how well all of you have done and I am sorry to say I envy you.  Dont get me wrong, I know it is hard for everyone.  But I have a hard time walking to the bathroom somedays and here some of you are running and walking miles daily.  I was not an incredibly fit person, before but I was no couch potato either.  I walked all day at my job, and exercised 3-4 days a week at curves.   It amazes me to see how well most of you do.  I have been out of work since surgery, and have no idea when I will return.  I hope rads is easier.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 09:53PM cherneski wrote: Today was tx 5 of 6 tc.  Thank God only 1 more to go.  Onc. is on vacation so I saw nurse practitioner.  I love her.  We went over my SEs for almost 2 hours and came up with a plan to help me stop pucking.  Lets hope it works.  Pain management is the same, oxys and percs.  I am allowed to take oxys 10 hours apart instead of 12, and double up on percs when needed.  But percs make me sick, so its either pain or puke. Confirmed sever neuroapthy in my feet during last TX and mild in feet and right hand now.  We cut my Taxotere in half to avoid it becoming a permanent thing and altering my life in a bad way.   It is bad enough I am losing feeling in my hand (probably perm.) I dont want severe pain in my feet permanently! Also found out I am Grade 3 not 2, makes me wonder what else I wasnt brought up to speed on.    I was told I was going to need chemo before they did surgery.  I dont think that is the norm. is it?  I thought unless they knew the tumor was large over about 4cm, then they knew they wanted to to chemo, but besides that it would depend.  IDK, finding out I am stage 3 not 2 then grade 3 not 2 then this is the best one... I am given medication in with my chemo to give me amnesia!  I lost 5 days last round so I asked about it and sure enough was told I am being given meds to cause this.  For those of you for having surgery coming up! hang in there, if you can make it through chemo you can make it through anything.  Surgery was the easy part for me.   Yes you will be tired, and yes you are tired of being tired.  But sorry to say you are strong!  And you will make it through with flying colors!  Just think if this whiner for NJ can do it you can too!  I wish you gals/ and Tom could have seen me before this.  I was a fighter.  Now I am not a fighter I just show up.  So Ladies if you have no fight because you are too tired, just show up.  Much love to all of you as what you are walking into is not easy.  There are a ton of emotions.  I just showed up.  The surgery was the easy part, the chemo is not.  That is why I am so confident for all of you.  You will do great, you are already through the hardest physical part.  Much luv from NJ  hugs

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 06:37PM cherneski wrote: I put my big girl panties on and went.  I puked on the way there because my nerves were just so shot out.  I have never puked from nerves before and I have been in some crappy situations in life (like we all have).  I forgot my xanex~ not good.  I pretty much started crying from the minute I walked in the door ( I was never a crier before this).  Dr. asked me if I needed more xanex, I guess I looked that bad.  I went back to change and she talked to hubby for a while.  He explained to her the he!! I went through with chemo.  I let her know just how sick of this God forsaken DISease I am!  Ok here is the good news, I am only getting 25 tx, so only 5 weeks!  Yipeeee! And here is the bad news, they are radiating my arm pit along with my chest wall.  I already have mild lymphedema, and she warned me how much more at risk I am for it getting worse.  I will have to be very careful for the rest of my life as to not make it worse.  And she strongly recommends I do not ever go back to my job.   Needless to say I had a total melt down.  I have known for sometime I may not be able to return to my job, but today I heard it for sure.  I went to talk to the social worker (I know pretty much everyone at the cancer center) and I just lost it!  What am I supposed to do?  I am only 38!  SSDI will only approve you if your unable to do any job.  And only after my Drs say I am unable to work.  Then they make you see the SSDI Drs. who try to deny you.  I was assured I am not able to work for some time, and not able to return to my job unless I want to put my health in jeopardy.  I am not willing to do that.  As for any other job, we have to wait and see if the neuropathy gets better, or worse.  Wait and see if my pain goes away.  And wait and see if I will stop being a head case.   I go for my simulation on Monday the 2nd, and start on Monday the 9th.   I was told I am grieving.  Yeah I guess I am. Hugs to everyone.  Sorry to be such a bummer.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2010 12:38PM cherneski wrote: I posted my color of "none" because I dont wear one because no more boobies.  I did not see any connection how this "game" is connected to BC awareness.  But I did it as fun to keep the guys guessing.  I did find it was fun that ppl wanted to know.  But like I said I saw no connection with awareness.  I am sorry you got upset about it.  We know that so many people get so involved in Oct. but then unless you are one of us they forget about it the other 11 months out of the year.  At least it brought bc to the front for a few days again.  Did it do any good?  Probably not.   As far as ppl being less than nice to you about your post, screw them.  We all deal with this dreadful disease in our own way.  I for one am the angry one.  Was angry at dx and angry now.  Not angry that I got it, angry that it exists at all.   Hope you have a better day.

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 05:56PM cherneski wrote: Jen, I just about lost it towards the end of chemo (I lose it often ), to me the end of tx meant it could come back.  As much as I hated chemo I did not want it to end because of that.  I was terrified!  I am a realist, I know (think) that my age and stage of dx has shortened my life and although I want to live to 100, I doubt it will happen.  But I dont plan for my death. I want to see my grandkids, great grandkids and I will not go down without a fight, just like I know you wont.  Enjoy today.  We do not know what tomorrow will bring.  Our future is uncertain, and only God knows when it is our time cancer or not.  You are so cared for by so many, I hope you can take some time to absorb that.  Enjoy today.  Much love Deb

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 02:46AM cherneski wrote: Ok, my family Dr. called in the perscription yesterday so at least when I am losing it I can try to calm down.  She told me she doesnt want to give them to me because they are very addicting.  Yeah well I am not eating them like candy.  I just want to be able to take something when all of a sudden I am losing my mind.  I am pretty much staying positive.  Although there are moments that the unknown just takes over my crazy mind.  The only family history of BC in my family is my grandmother (my dads mom) and that when she was about 65 or even older.  And I know that is in my favor.  Also if there is anything of concern they are catching it very early. The nurse that told me that was supposed to fax over the results to my OBGYN on Friday never did.  So tomorrow I am calling and demanding she fax them to me.    From everything that I have read here and on the web in general until they do the biopsy they cant tell anything for sure.  So even if the report does not look favorable it could be nothing.   Thank you all for being so kind.  I am keeping positive right now and hopefully wont lose my mind today.

Posts.Content: cherneski wrote: Very nice to meet you all but I wish it was under better circumstances.  I have been watching and reading just like everyone else.   I am scared, confused, angry and stressed beyond.  I found a lump in left breast in August 2008 went to Dr. he was not concerned but sent me for a mammogram.  At the Mammo they did an ultrasound on the right breast.  Left breast is fine.  Right breast has cysts, saw the breast specialist and was told come back in 6 months he was not concerned, which I did.  So I go for the mammo, and was told they won't do another US unless there is something of concern.  Then they did the us, then I was told to have an MRI.  Went to see BS and he said I really have nothing to worry about but we will do the MRI just in case.  Had the MRI last Saturday.  Get a call from the DR. Tuesday that now I need a stereotatic core biopsy (mammotome).  Mammo shows triangle shaped stellate breast lesion.  Then the nurse tells me that she can't tell me the results of the MRI because she is not a Dr. and it does not look favorable.  My BS is out until Tuesday, so she forwarded my results to my OBGYN so he can at least speak with me tomorrow.  I go for the biopsy this coming Tuesday and to see the BS the following Tuesday.  I do not deal well with stress (I know none of us do) but I am losing it!  I requested my family Dr. give me some Zanex so I can get through this a little easier, she never called it in.  I am tired but cant sleep, I am hungry but cant eat.  My husband is not dealing with this well; he won't talk to me about it.  I know he is terrified, but so am I and this is my body.  Sorry to ramble on and on but I really feel like I have no one to talk to.  If anyone has had similar dealings please let me know.  I want to know what to expect.  I am sorry if I come across angry, I am just so scared. Deborah dx 38 DCIS, IDC, ILC, BRCA- 6 rounds Taxotere+Cytoxin, 25 rads. Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 05:33AM cherneski wrote: jc3win~ I had a good laugh at the rockin the steroid face.  I cant believe how fat/swollen I am.  Pure~ I look about 15 months pregnant right now with how bloated my belly is.  Sometimes I go out without my boobs on and I am sure ppl wonder if I am pregnant as the belly then sticks out so far, I know they want to ask.  Not that it doesnt stick out that much with the boobs.  Things like that make me snicker to myself.                                                                             Mamita49~ OMG, that is one of the best ones yet!  I would have had a hard time not making her hit the floor. I have to agree people dont know what to say, and even when you gently guide them the still say stupid things.  The thing I had the hardest time with was when I would tell people assertively "that is not helpful" and they would get angry with me.  I lose control of my mouth and that would really test me.  I told my sister that one day and she said "what do you want me to say this all fusking sucks?"  I told her yep cause it does, there is nothing you can do or say to make it any better it just sucks.  With our txs we dont wither away to nothing like a lot of cancer patients do.  As most of us dont lose lots of weight in no time, a lot of us gain a bit real quick.  People expect us to look thin, weak, pale.  I look swollen and rosey, I think I look like a colorful version of the mitchellen tire guy.  My skin is smooth as silk and I almost glow, like I did when I was pregnant.  Maybe being pregnant you glow twice as much~lol

Posts.Content: cherneski wrote: OK, so most of you know I am crazy.  I have been on xanex since just before dx because the thought of all of this was just way too much.    You all also know that I have terrible SEs, from sickness, to neuapathy (still cant spell it), to pain, Pain and MORE PAIN from the chemo.  My onc. may make me make up the difference in the lessened dosage of Taxotere because the dropped it 50% tx #5.                                                                                                          But if not my last chemo will be next Monday Oct 5th.  So I should be jumping for joy; right?  I should be so happy that I will not feel sick, tired and in pain all the time; right? NOPE~ now I am freaking out that chemo is ending!  I so dont want to be one of those people that is looking for the negative.  I want to be normal.  I want to be happy.  I should be happy.  But I am now terrified!  Once chemo stops cancer can come back.  Or they might find out it didnt work.  When I was dx, I was more worried about recon than cancer (at this point I dont care if I do recon).  Then I focused on sx.  Now I focus on chemo.  For some reason the closer I get to the end of chemo the more real it is that I have CANCER.  I have cancer.  I have cancer and without chemo it can come back.  Why am I so scared?  Please someone tell me I am not crazy that someone has felt this way. Deborah dx 38 DCIS, IDC, ILC, BRCA- 6 rounds Taxotere+Cytoxin, 25 rads. Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 04:51PM cherneski wrote: As always Thank You all very much!  I am secretly wanting Onc. to make me come back for the rest of my Taxotere tx that they didnt give me last round.  Then I think that is sick in the head cause it makes me so sick.  IDK some minutes I am ok, and other times I am a launatic.  I guess it is par for the course.  I asked this on another thread but you gals really know your stuff so here goes... Before I had surgery they didnt know the size of the tumors exactly, but I guess they knew they were pretty small, well small enough they didnt need to do chemo before surgery.  But there was no question at all that I was getting chemo.  I was told by the BS in his office I will be getting it, the day I was told I have cancer.  I thought it depended on the size and your onco score (or what ever that is).  They did say something about my age being a factor.  Apparently the younger you are the worse it is, or something.  It was funny that I dont feel SO young and all I kept hearing is how young I am. So why was there never a question about it?  There was the question on if I would need rads; which I do because of the amount and size of the nodes. And... I am gonna be put on Tamoxifen for 3 years, then 8 years of something else.  Onc. says we will decide what at the time.  But 8 years; 11 years total.  OMG is anyone else getting told they will have that tx for that long?

Posts.Content: cherneski wrote: To:               YOU   Date:              TODAY From:             GOD Subject:         YOURSELF Reference:    LIFE   This is God.  Today I will be handling All of your problems for you.  I  do Not need your help.  So, have a nice day.. I love you. P.S.    And, remember... If life happens to deliver a situation to you that you cannot handle, do Not attempt to resolve it yourself!   Kindly put it in the SFGTD (something for  God to do) box.  I will get to it in MY TIME.  All situations will be resolved, but in My  time, not  yours.    Once the matter is placed into the box, do not hold onto it by worrying about it.  Instead, focus on all the wonderful things that are present in your life now.    If you find yourself stuck in traffic, don't despair. There are people in this world for whom driving is an unheard of privilege. Should you have a bad day at work; think of the man who has been out of work for  years.   Should you despair over a relationship gone bad; think of the person who has never known what it's like to love and be loved in return.   Should you grieve the passing of another weekend; think of the woman in dire straits, working twelve hours a day, seven days a week to feed her children.   Should your car break down, leaving you miles away from assistance; think of the paraplegic who would love the opportunity to take that walk.   Should you notice a new gray hair in the mirror; think of the cancer patient in chemo who wishes she had hair to examine.  Should you find yourself at a loss and pondering what is life all about, asking what is my purpose? Be thankful. There are those who didn't live long enough to get the opportunity.   Should you find yourself the victim of other people's bitterness, ignorance, smallness or insecurities; remember, things could be worse.  You could be one of them!   Should you decide to send this to a friend; Thank you.  You may have touched their life in ways you will never know! Now, you have a nice day...God   God  has seen you struggling, God   says it's over. Deborah dx 38 DCIS, IDC, ILC, BRCA- 6 rounds Taxotere+Cytoxin, 25 rads. Dx 4/9/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 7/13 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 5/6/2009 Mastectomy: Left, Right Chemotherapy 6/5/2009 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 11/15/2009 Breast, Lymph nodes Surgery 7/14/2010 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Hormonal Therapy 8/17/2014 Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
